sections.name: Information notice and consent form for candidate crewmembers
sections.content:
1. Data Processing, Data Retention and Processing Purposes
1.1 The Company, in its capacity as a data controller, processes your personal data collected either from you and/or a third
party (e.g. former employers, manning agents or other recruiters, et. al.) in accordance with Regulation (EU) 2016/679 on the
protection of natural persons with regard to the processing of personal data and on the free movement of such data, the
applicable legislation in relation to personal data and shipping practice. More specifically, we process passport, identity and
contact information, training and education data, prior and current employment information, background security checks,
photo, your application to the Company and your communications with it, as well as any other data necessary in connection
with the purposes described below.
1.2 The Company will retain your personal data for six (6) months after the completion of the selection process in relation to
the position, for which you have applied. This period may be extended, if this is required in order for the Company to comply
with its legal obligations towards the competent authorities or third parties, due to applicable provisions on data retention
periods or in order for the Company to establish, exercise or defend legal claims. If your application is successful, we will
inform you about the new applicable retention periods.
1.3 We process your data in order to select the appropriate personnel for the position for which you have applied pursuant to
our recruitment criteria, to comply with our legal obligations, to establish, exercise or defend legal claims and to ensure the
safety of our staff, our premises and of the vessels we manage. If you provide your consent, we will process your data in
order to select the appropriate personnel for a future position, other than that for which you have applied.
2. Third party data transfers
We will not transfer your personal data to any third parties to the extent that your application is not successful or unless such
transfer is required by law or by an order of a competent authority.
3. Your rights
You have the right to: (a) request access to your data and to information relating to the processing of your data, (b) request
corrections and/or completion of your data, (c) request the deletion of your data, (d) request the restriction of the scope of
processing, the way we are processing your data, as well as the purposes for which we are processing them, (e) receive the
data you provide to us in a structured, commonly used and machine-readable format, transmit them to another data
controller, and/or request us to transmit them to another data controller, if technically feasible, (f) object to the processing of
your data, on grounds relating to your particular situation, and (g) file a complaint before the competent data protection
authority. So far as the processing relies upon your consent, you have the right to withdraw such consent at any time. To
exercise your rights, please contact us as stated below at 5.
4. Legal basis for processing
The Company processes your personal data because the processing is necessary in order for the Company to:
(a) take steps at your request prior to entering into an employment agreement with you;
(b) process your data for the purposes your consent, where applicable; and/or
(c) to pursue its legitimate interests, such as to comply with its employee-related procedures, to fulfil its manning needs, to
ensure the safety and security of its staff, of the vessels it manages and of its premises, to comply with its legal obligations
and with industry-specific requirements imposed by charterers, to establish, exercise or defend legal claims and to identify
candidates;
(d) to establish, exercise or defend legal claims.
The provision of some of the above personal data is required by law or by contract. Therefore, if you do not provide us with
your data, we will not be able to process your application to work in the Company.
6. Communication
You can communicate with the Company as follows:
UNION MARINE ENTERPRISES SA - [+30 2104223081] - [mail@ume.gr]
ACKNOWLEDGEMENT OF RECEIPT - I have received the above information
CONSENT - I consent to the processing of my personal data by the Company for two (2) years, in order to consider
me as a candidate for a position other than the one I have applied for in the future.
PLACE
SIGNATURE
DATE
SIGNED
01
Issue Date: 30.05.2025
Rev. No.: 00
Rev. Date: N/A
Page: 5 of 5

      "name": "Information notice and consent form for candidate crewmembers",
      "content": "1. Data Processing, Data Retention and Processing Purposes
1.1 The Company, in its capacity as a data controller, processes your personal data collected either from you and/or a third
party (e.g. former employers, manning agents or other recruiters, et. al.) in accordance with Regulation (EU) 2016/679 on the
protection of natural persons with regard to the processing of personal data and on the free movement of such data, the
applicable legislation in relation to personal data and shipping practice. More specifically, we process passport, identity and
contact information, training and education data, prior and current employment information, background security checks,
photo, your application to the Company and your communications with it, as well as any other data necessary in connection
with the purposes described below.
1.2 The Company will retain your personal data for six (6) months after the completion of the selection process in relation to
the position, for which you have applied. This period may be extended, if this is required in order for the Company to comply
with its legal obligations towards the competent authorities or third parties, due to applicable provisions on data retention
periods or in order for the Company to establish, exercise or defend legal claims. If your application is successful, we will
inform you about the new applicable retention periods.
1.3 We process your data in order to select the appropriate personnel for the position for which you have applied pursuant to
our recruitment criteria, to comply with our legal obligations, to establish, exercise or defend legal claims and to ensure the
safety of our staff, our premises and of the vessels we manage. If you provide your consent, we will process your data in
order to select the appropriate personnel for a future position, other than that for which you have applied.
2. Third party data transfers
We will not transfer your personal data to any third parties to the extent that your application is not successful or unless such
transfer is required by law or by an order of a competent authority.
3. Your rights
You have the right to: (a) request access to your data and to information relating to the processing of your data, (b) request
corrections and/or completion of your data, (c) request the deletion of your data, (d) request the restriction of the scope of
processing, the way we are processing your data, as well as the purposes for which we are processing them, (e) receive the
data you provide to us in a structured, commonly used and machine-readable format, transmit them to another data
controller, and/or request us to transmit them to another data controller, if technically feasible, (f) object to the processing of
your data, on grounds relating to your particular situation, and (g) file a complaint before the competent data protection
authority. So far as the processing relies upon your consent, you have the right to withdraw such consent at any time. To
exercise your rights, please contact us as stated below at 5.
4. Legal basis for processing
The Company processes your personal data because the processing is necessary in order for the Company to:
(a) take steps at your request prior to entering into an employment agreement with you;
(b) process your data for the purposes your consent, where applicable; and/or
(c) to pursue its legitimate interests, such as to comply with its employee-related procedures, to fulfil its manning needs, to
ensure the safety and security of its staff, of the vessels it manages and of its premises, to comply with its legal obligations
and with industry-specific requirements imposed by charterers, to establish, exercise or defend legal claims and to identify
candidates;
(d) to establish, exercise or defend legal claims.
The provision of some of the above personal data is required by law or by contract. Therefore, if you do not provide us with
your data, we will not be able to process your application to work in the Company.
6. Communication
You can communicate with the Company as follows:

CONSENT - I consent to the processing of my personal data by the Company for two (2) years, in order to consider

gemini.title: Chapter 7.7 - DRUG AND ALCOHOL (D&A) CONTROL

sections.name: Drug & Alcohol
sections.content:
The Company's D&A policy and requirements apply to all seafarers onboard and all personnel, contractors, employees of contractors, visitors, supernumeraries, etc. who visit or sail with a Company's ship.
The root-cause diagram displayed in Figure 1 serves as an industry bow tie that illustrates the primary factors that may lead to drug and alcohol use, as well as the different circumstances under which this may occur. It also highlights the relationship between these factors and the effects of drug and alcohol use on an individual's capability, ultimately linking it to increased risk of incidents.
An effective approach to drug and alcohol management is to prioritize prevention measures.
Key: Dark blue represents key elements related to drug and alcohol use; Light blue represents other factors.
Figure 1: Root causes and effects of drug and alcohol use

sections.name: Purpose
sections.content:
To:
Define the procedures to prevent the possession and use of alcohol or illegal drugs or the improper use of prescribed drugs onboard.
Present supportive measures, as well as testing programs and disciplinary measures.
Ensure that NO employee of a managed ship undertakes duty under the influence or suspected influence of D&A.

sections.name: Prohibited usage
sections.content: The misuse of legitimate drugs or the use, possession, distribution, or sale of illegal or unprescribed drugs, the consumption of alcoholic beverages in any manner other than as prescribed herein, and the possession of alcoholic beverages onboard is prohibited. More specifically:

sections.name: Prohibited alcohol abuse
sections.content:
All seafarers and visitors:
Do not store any alcohol in private places onboard (cabin, luggage, etc.).
Do not consume any alcohol onboard, except for the beer usage allowed.
ONLY a limited beer consumption is allowed onboard and under controlled conditions:
1 can (330 ml) of beer of <4% Alc. by Vol, per person per day, for a maximum of 2 days per week
Beer is served in an opened can during a meal, after the Master's approval.
Cook: Keep records in form DA 003.
Alcohol beverages are stored in a secure and locked place at all times under the responsibility of the Master.
DO NOT consume alcohol at least 4 hours before:
returning to ship from shore leave.
taking over a watch or any other scheduled work.
Table 1: Approximate Alcohol Unit Conversions

sections.name: Prohibited drug usage
sections.content:
All seafarers and visitors:
DO NOT use or possess illegal drugs or substances, including mind-altering substances, other than non-intoxicating or non-judgment-impairing drugs.
Remember: it is a dismissible offence if you use, possess, or are under the influence of any illegal drug or substance. Depending on the case, notification of authorities and legal prosecution may be necessary.
If you are using prescription or non-prescription drugs, review Section 7.7.2.3 below.

sections.name: Responsibilities
sections.content:
Master:
Monitor the implementation of this procedure and enforce the D&A policy on all persons onboard.
Conduct unannounced D&A tests onboard.
Help external medical contractors perform D&A tests.
NEVER allow a crew member under the influence of drugs or alcohol to perform any duty and/or leave the ship.
NEVER allow any third party under the influence of D&A to board the ship.
If you suspect that a person onboard is under the influence of drugs or alcohol, immediately relieve him from his duties and place him under observation until the influence of drugs or alcohol subsides. Should this person disobey or resist, escort him to his quarters, lock him in, if necessary, and inform the DPA immediately.
Cook:
Get the Master's approval before serving beer cans.
Serve open beer cans in Officers and Crew Messrooms only during meals in accordance with Section 7.7.1.2.1 above.
Keep daily records of Alcohol distribution and consumption in relevant form.
Marine / Operations Department: Supply Company’s vessels only with cans (330 ml) of beer (<3.5% Alc. by Vol) taking into consideration the number of crew onboard, the quantity of previous requisitions placed by the ships, etc.

sections.name: Procedure
sections.content:
Any tests conducted are confidential, and the results will only be communicated to the DPA and, if applicable, to third parties responsible for handling events of D&A violations.
It is prohibited to submit persons of any protected characteristic (like age, civil status, color, culture, descent, disability, gender, language, maternity/paternity, national or ethnic origin, political opinion, pregnancy, race, religion, sexual orientation, etc.) to excessive testing regarding D&A use or to draw any inference regarding D&A use.
Any action taken will consider the human rights of the person involved. Testing will be made only after consent has been given by the person being tested; however, refusal to do testing may lead to disciplinary action.

sections.name: Testing procedures
sections.content:
Seafarer: You are subject to alcohol and drug testing:
Before employment on a ship (employment depends on the D&A test results).
During monthly unannounced alcohol tests and quarterly/other tests following DPA request.
During semi-annual unannounced D&A tests by the external medical contractor.
In case of drug or alcohol use suspicion.
If the Master or the Company deem a D&A test necessary.
If Port Authorities request.
In case of an incident onboard (as per Chapter 9).
When you board/return from ashore if needed.
When you return to work post treatment, if required, depending on the treatment.
Marine / Operations Department / Master: Inform all contractors, their employees, supernumeraries, visitors, etc. who visit the ship about the applicable D&A restrictions before or immediately after their boarding.
Master:
Perform random searches of the crew's accommodation and storage spaces before and after departure from any suspicious Port, or after another ship coming alongside, (e.g., a bunkering barge), if you deem it necessary.
Document these searches in the Bridge Log Book.
Perform random checks on the effectiveness of the gangway checks.
Master / OOW: Be particularly vigilant during the ship's stay or departure from a Port.
Gangway Watch:
Report to the OOW upon visitors/contractors/shore-leave crewmembers boarding the ship.
Check visitors, non-crew members and shore-leave crewmembers according to SSP, to verify that they do not have any or are not under the influence of drugs or alcohol, especially seafarers who have to take over any watch duties within the next 4 hours.
Report to the OOW immediately, and ask the Master to initiate a testing process, if you deem it necessary.

sections.name: Discipline on D&A policy
sections.content:
Situations or behaviours that are considered as a proven breach of this Policy and may lead to initiation of a stand-down procedure or even termination of employment include:
Refusal to test, interfering with or obstructing a sampling and testing process, or otherwise failing to cooperate or comply.
Impaired cognitive function leading to impaired capability, as an effect of D&A policy breach (being under the influence of a prohibited substance).
Failing to stand down after the Master suspended the person following a reading above the permitted level after the 2nd breathalyzer test or any other confirmed positive result or non-compliance with orders given after a positive test result.
Test falsification.
Positive test results.
Use, distribution, sale, or possession of alcoholic beverages or drugs.
Master: If a person onboard exhibits signs and symptoms of D&A misuse and has allegedly breached the D&A policy:
Conduct a breathalyzer test and/or collect samples for drug screening.
Record the name of the person along with the breathalyzer reading as evidence.
Interview the offender on the alleged breach of the D&A policy.
Temporarily stand down from all duties and retest him with the breathalyzer after 15 minutes, but no later than 30 minutes. If the reading remains above the permitted level after the 2nd test, suspend the individual from duty permanently.
Let the offender prepare a written statement and, if he wishes, call witnesses to provide evidence in his defense.
Collect all evidence, statements, etc. related to the case and initiate an investigation.
Decide if there is proof that the individual breached the D&A policy.
Inform the Company immediately and issue a Dismissal Notice.
Record all the above in the D&A Test log (form DA 001) and sign the entry with a witness.
Company Management: Hold a disciplinary hearing before the offender’s dismissal.
Master: in case the offender is a contractor/supplier:
Disembark the contractor/supplier from the ship immediately.
Complete and send to Company the form Q 006 “Contractors Performance Feedback Report by Ship”.
DPA: Inform the contracting company in case the offender is a contractor/supplier. Keep a note in the relevant “Supplier/Contractor Approved list”.

sections.name: Alcoholmeters
sections.content:
There are handheld breathalyzers (alcoholmeters) onboard the ships.
C/O:
Keep alcoholmeters in good condition and calibrate them (if applicable) as per the maker's instructions (keep records in form M 015 "Equipment Calibration Record").
The alcohol measurement by breathalyzers is usually in mg of alcohol per liter of exhaled air [mg/l], while recommended alcohol levels are usually in grams per liter of blood (or in mg per 100 ml blood). If the concentration measurement is by a blood test, the following approximate formula applies to the unit conversion from gr/l blood (or mg/100 ml blood) to mg/l exhaled air:
(Measurement in mg/l air) = ½ x (Measurement in gr/l blood)
Or (Measurement in mg/l air) = ½oo x (Measurement in mg/100ml blood)
For example, if the alcohol concentration level is 0.40 gr/l blood, it is approximately equivalent to ½ x 0.40 = 0.20 mg/l air, measurable by the ship's breathalyzer. Alternatively, if the blood concentration is in mg/100 ml, then a level of 40mg/100 ml blood is equivalent to ½oo x 40 = 0.20 mg/l measured by the breathalyzer and vice-versa. During a blood test, the alcohol concentration is already in mg per 100 ml blood, and no conversion is necessary.
Immediately request the replacement of a defective unit.
Submit timely replacement requests for consumable items to the Company as a requisition (using form M 000 "Requisition Form – Provisions, Consumables, Spares"), ensuring that the onboard supply is sufficient for the resupply period.
Train the Senior Officers on the operation of this equipment.

sections.name: Alcohol Testing onboard
sections.content:
DPA: Monthly and whenever appropriate, ask the Master to perform an alcohol test on all onboard personnel.
Master:
Confirm receipt and perform the requested tests within the next 2 hours.
Supervise the testing of seafarers with another Officer as a witness.
Record testing results in form DA 001.
Enter the testing date in the Bridge Log Book.
Report to the DPA immediately after testing.
C/O: Perform the Master’s Alcohol test under the presence of the C/E.
S/Ts:
Perform random searches of the crew's accommodation and storage spaces for D&A.
Perform random alcohol tests while visiting the ship, when appropriate.
Emphasize understanding and verification of the key elements of the D&A Policy.

sections.name: Drug control
sections.content:
Illegal drugs include but are not limited to, Heroin, Marijuana, Cocaine, Opiates, Amphetamines, Cannabis, PCP (Phencyclidine), Barbiturates, Methadone, etc.
Master: Several medicines in the ship's medical inventory list are drugs, e.g., sedatives, opiates, etc. Always keep them locked. Only you can authorize their use.
Seafarers using prescription or non-prescription drugs:
Provide details (type and quantity, along with side effects affecting performance & safety) during the pre-employment medical examination.
Provide details to Master when joining a ship, presenting the valid doctor's prescription. If the prescription of such drugs is issued during your contract onboard, provide the prescription as soon as prescribed.
Master:
Upon notification by the joining seafarer:
Make an entry in the ship's Medical log.
If unsure about such drugs' effects, consult the Company to seek clarifications on the effects of taking this medication.
If you take a prescribed drug, notify the Company before taking command.
If the prescription of such drugs is issued during your contract onboard, notify the Company as soon as prescribed.

sections.name: Recommended drug panel cut-offs
sections.content: Cut-off levels vary from one drug to another. Appendix I includes the recommended cut-off levels for a range of drugs and specimen types (urine, hair, and oral fluid), based on the IPIECA/IOGP “Oil and gas contractor D&A testing guidelines”.

sections.name: Drug test kits
sections.content:
There are urine test kits onboard the ships, for specimen collection, in case of need and when it is impossible to get an external medical contractor onboard:
Master:
Keep onboard a minimum of 1 box of 30 urine test kits.
Take all appropriate hygiene measures during sample collection, e.g., wear disposable gloves.
After you seal all bottles and chain of custody forms in the respective bags, place the test kits in a suitable container, and pack them for shipment to the medical contractor.
Ask the agent at the first Port of call to send the package urgently.
Inform the Company about landing the samples and their dispatch method.
C/O:
Maintain the inventory of urine test kits in the Medical Chest form / inventory.
Submit timely replacement requests to the Company as a requisition (using form M 000 "Requisition Form – Provisions, Consumables, Spares"), ensuring that the onboard supply is sufficient for the resupply period.

sections.name: Drug Trafficking
sections.content:
Follow the guidelines below to minimize the risk of drug trafficking/abuse onboard:
Master:
Arrange a detailed search of the ship before sailing from Ports with a high risk for drug smuggling, considering the following:
All ship areas are searchable.
The search team consisting of 2-3 persons, headed by a Senior Officer, must be trustworthy and keep the issue confidential.
The team has the master key(s), torches, mirrors, etc. to search for all hidden places reachable by the crew.
The team has several padlocks to ensure that NOBODY enters the searched places after the check. All rooms, stores, and compartments are locked after the search until the entire search is complete.
Ensure that places not used regularly, e.g., empty cabins and storerooms, are locked, and seafarers cannot enter them without your authorization.
Tips for the Search Team
Search the E/R, accommodation area, double-bottomed drums, storerooms, refrigerators, paint lockers, electrical panels, ventilation ducts, etc.
The smuggler might divide the drugs into smaller packages to increase the possibility of keeping them undetected.
It is rare but possible to find items inside the oil or water tanks, in fire extinguishers, in the wall, under the floor or ceiling, in bilges, etc.
A suspicious package might carry fingerprints, which must remain intact.
Master:
Enter the search results in form DA 002.
In the case of positive findings, send a report to the Company requesting instructions.
Notify the Customs of any suspicious circumstances or behavior onboard or if you discover any suspicious parcels or goods.

sections.name: Independent D&A testing
sections.content:
The Company has contracted an external medical contractor / specialized independent agency to perform annual unannounced D&A tests.
This contractor is responsible for the results' integrity and informs the Master and the Company about any positive or negative test results.
The above tests DO NOT exclude the Master.
All Seafarers:
You are subject to unannounced D&A tests scheduled by the Company. Under the Master's supervision, follow their sampling instructions to ensure the results' validity.
If you are taking any medicine, mention it during the test and provide details about it to the external contractor. The Master must verify your statement by checking the relevant entries in the Medical log.
Master:
Forward the results and consult the Company if a seafarer's test is positive.
In case the test produces doubtful results, repeat the test.

sections.name: Post-incident D&A testing
sections.content: Master: For Category 3 & 4 incidents, as per Chapter 9, perform the following D&A testing on each involved individual:

sections.name: Alcohol Testing
sections.content:
Perform alcohol testing within 2 hours after the incident, unless it is impossible due to safety concerns. In this case, complete the testing as soon as possible, but no later than 8 hours after the incident.
If the testing is impossible within 8 hours, record the reason in the Bridge Log Book.
In case the test produces doubtful results, repeat the tests.

sections.name: Drug Testing
sections.content:
In case of an incident where it is impossible to get an external medical contractor onboard, collect the specimens within 32 hours from the incident; if this is not possible, collect them as soon as possible.
If the collection is impossible, record the reason in the Bridge Log Book.

sections.name: D&A awareness and preventive measures
sections.content:
To prevent D&A abuse and motivate seafarers to observe the D&A policy:
The Company:
Sends onboard relevant industry guidelines, initiates Campaigns and informs the seafarers about the adverse effects of drugs and alcohol.
Provides support and help, if needed, with confidentiality.
Master / Senior Officer:
Communicate the onboard rules to all persons onboard.
Post the D&A policy and relative posters in the ship's accommodation.
Use every opportunity to promote the Company's D&A Policy.
Encourage activities to compensate for the lack of social life/recreation and to reduce boredom and conditions potentially leading to D&A use.
Organize activities during the off-watch hours, encourage hobbies and educational activities, and ensure that provided recreation means are always available.
Make sure your crew knows you are always open to discuss any personal problems.

sections.name: Recommended drug panel cut-off
sections.content:
Below Table 1 lists the cut-off levels for a range of drugs and specimen types (urine, hair and oral fluid). Laboratories and contractors may test at levels lower than the cut-offs specified in Table 1; however, a lower cut-off than those specified is not required.
Table 2: Recommended cut-offs of drugs and specimen types

Conduct a breathalyzer test and/or collect samples for drug screening.
Record the name of the person along with the breathalyzer reading as evidence.
Interview the offender on the alleged breach of the D&A policy.
Temporarily stand down from all duties and retest him with the breathalyzer after 15 minutes, but no later than 30 minutes. If the reading remains above the permitted level after the 2nd test, suspend the individual from duty permanently.
Let the offender prepare a written statement and, if he wishes, call witnesses to provide evidence in his defense.
Collect all evidence, statements, etc. related to the case and initiate an investigation.
Decide if there is proof that the individual breached the D&A policy.
Inform the Company immediately and issue a Dismissal Notice.
Record all the above in the D&A Test log (form DA 001) and sign the entry with a witness.
Company Management: Hold a disciplinary hearing before the offender’s dismissal.
Master: in case the offender is a contractor/supplier:
Disembark the contractor/supplier from the ship immediately.
Complete and send to Company the form Q 006 “Contractors Performance Feedback Report by Ship”.
DPA: Inform the contracting company in case the offender is a contractor/supplier. Keep a note in the relevant “Supplier/Contractor Approved list”."
    },
    {
      "name": "Alcoholmeters",
      "content": "There are handheld breathalyzers (alcoholmeters) onboard the ships.
C/O:
Keep alcoholmeters in good condition and calibrate them (if applicable) as per the maker's instructions (keep records in form M 015 "Equipment Calibration Record").
The alcohol measurement by breathalyzers is usually in mg of alcohol per liter of exhaled air [mg/l], while recommended alcohol levels are usually in grams per liter of blood (or in mg per 100 ml blood). If the concentration measurement is by a blood test, the following approximate formula applies to the unit conversion from gr/l blood (or mg/100 ml blood) to mg/l exhaled air:
(Measurement in mg/l air) = ½ x (Measurement in gr/l blood)
Or (Measurement in mg/l air) = ½oo x (Measurement in mg/100ml blood)
For example, if the alcohol concentration level is 0.40 gr/l blood, it is approximately equivalent to ½ x 0.40 = 0.20 mg/l air, measurable by the ship's breathalyzer. Alternatively, if the blood concentration is in mg/100 ml, then a level of 40mg/100 ml blood is equivalent to ½oo x 40 = 0.20 mg/l measured by the breathalyzer and vice-versa. During a blood test, the alcohol concentration is already in mg per 100 ml blood, and no conversion is necessary.
Immediately request the replacement of a defective unit.
Submit timely replacement requests for consumable items to the Company as a requisition (using form M 000 "Requisition Form – Provisions, Consumables, Spares"), ensuring that the onboard supply is sufficient for the resupply period.
Train the Senior Officers on the operation of this equipment."
    },
    {
      "name": "Alcohol Testing onboard",
      "content": "DPA: Monthly and whenever appropriate, ask the Master to perform an alcohol test on all onboard personnel.
Master:
Confirm receipt and perform the requested tests within the next 2 hours.
Supervise the testing of seafarers with another Officer as a witness.
Record testing results in form DA 001.
Enter the testing date in the Bridge Log Book.
Report to the DPA immediately after testing.
C/O: Perform the Master’s Alcohol test under the presence of the C/E.
S/Ts:
Perform random searches of the crew's accommodation and storage spaces for D&A.
Perform random alcohol tests while visiting the ship, when appropriate.
Emphasize understanding and verification of the key elements of the D&A Policy."
    },
    {
      "name": "Drug control",
      "content": "Illegal drugs include but are not limited to, Heroin, Marijuana, Cocaine, Opiates, Amphetamines, Cannabis, PCP (Phencyclidine), Barbiturates, Methadone, etc.
Master: Several medicines in the ship's medical inventory list are drugs, e.g., sedatives, opiates, etc. Always keep them locked. Only you can authorize their use.
Seafarers using prescription or non-prescription drugs:
Provide details (type and quantity, along with side effects affecting performance & safety) during the pre-employment medical examination.
Provide details to Master when joining a ship, presenting the valid doctor's prescription. If the prescription of such drugs is issued during your contract onboard, provide the prescription as soon as prescribed.
Master:
Upon notification by the joining seafarer:
Make an entry in the ship's Medical log.
If unsure about such drugs' effects, consult the Company to seek clarifications on the effects of taking this medication.
If you take a prescribed drug, notify the Company before taking command.
If the prescription of such drugs is issued during your contract onboard, notify the Company as soon as prescribed."
    },
    {
      "name": "Recommended drug panel cut-offs",
      "content": "Cut-off levels vary from one drug to another. Appendix I includes the recommended cut-off levels for a range of drugs and specimen types (urine, hair, and oral fluid), based on the IPIECA/IOGP “Oil and gas contractor D&A testing guidelines”."
    },
    {
      "name": "Drug test kits",
      "content": "There are urine test kits onboard the ships, for specimen collection, in case of need and when it is impossible to get an external medical contractor onboard:
Master:
Keep onboard a minimum of 1 box of 30 urine test kits.
Take all appropriate hygiene measures during sample collection, e.g., wear disposable gloves.
After you seal all bottles and chain of custody forms in the respective bags, place the test kits in a suitable container, and pack them for shipment to the medical contractor.
Ask the agent at the first Port of call to send the package urgently.
Inform the Company about landing the samples and their dispatch method.
C/O:
Maintain the inventory of urine test kits in the Medical Chest form / inventory.
Submit timely replacement requests to the Company as a requisition (using form M 000 "Requisition Form – Provisions, Consumables, Spares"), ensuring that the onboard supply is sufficient for the resupply period."
    },
    {
      "name": "Drug Trafficking",
      "content": "Follow the guidelines below to minimize the risk of drug trafficking/abuse onboard:
Master:
Arrange a detailed search of the ship before sailing from Ports with a high risk for drug smuggling, considering the following:
All ship areas are searchable.
The search team consisting of 2-3 persons, headed by a Senior Officer, must be trustworthy and keep the issue confidential.
The team has the master key(s), torches, mirrors, etc. to search for all hidden places reachable by the crew.
The team has several padlocks to ensure that NOBODY enters the searched places after the check. All rooms, stores, and compartments are locked after the search until the entire search is complete.
Ensure that places not used regularly, e.g., empty cabins and storerooms, are locked, and seafarers cannot enter them without your authorization.
Tips for the Search Team
Search the E/R, accommodation area, double-bottomed drums, storerooms, refrigerators, paint lockers, electrical panels, ventilation ducts, etc.
The smuggler might divide the drugs into smaller packages to increase the possibility of keeping them undetected.
It is rare but possible to find items inside the oil or water tanks, in fire extinguishers, in the wall, under the floor or ceiling, in bilges, etc.
A suspicious package might carry fingerprints, which must remain intact.
Master:
Enter the search results in form DA 002.
In the case of positive findings, send a report to the Company requesting instructions.
Notify the Customs of any suspicious circumstances or behavior onboard or if you discover any suspicious parcels or goods."
    },
    {
      "name": "Independent D&A testing",
      "content": "The Company has contracted an external medical contractor / specialized independent agency to perform annual unannounced D&A tests.
This contractor is responsible for the results' integrity and informs the Master and the Company about any positive or negative test results.
The above tests DO NOT exclude the Master.
All Seafarers:
You are subject to unannounced D&A tests scheduled by the Company. Under the Master's supervision, follow their sampling instructions to ensure the results' validity.
If you are taking any medicine, mention it during the test and provide details about it to the external contractor. The Master must verify your statement by checking the relevant entries in the Medical log.
Master:
Forward the results and consult the Company if a seafarer's test is positive.
In case the test produces doubtful results, repeat the test."
    },
    {
      "name": "Post-incident D&A testing",
      "content": "Master: For Category 3 & 4 incidents, as per Chapter 9, perform the following D&A testing on each involved individual:"
    },
    {
      "name": "Alcohol Testing",
      "content": "Perform alcohol testing within 2 hours after the incident, unless it is impossible due to safety concerns. In this case, complete the testing as soon as possible, but no later than 8 hours after the incident.
If the testing is impossible within 8 hours, record the reason in the Bridge Log Book.
In case the test produces doubtful results, repeat the tests."
    },
    {
      "name": "Drug Testing",
      "content": "In case of an incident where it is impossible to get an external medical contractor onboard, collect the specimens within 32 hours from the incident; if this is not possible, collect them as soon as possible.
If the collection is impossible, record the reason in the Bridge Log Book."
    },
    {
      "name": "D&A awareness and preventive measures",
      "content": "To prevent D&A abuse and motivate seafarers to observe the D&A policy:
The Company:
Sends onboard relevant industry guidelines, initiates Campaigns and informs the seafarers about the adverse effects of drugs and alcohol.
Provides support and help, if needed, with confidentiality.
Master / Senior Officer:
Communicate the onboard rules to all persons onboard.
Post the D&A policy and relative posters in the ship's accommodation.
Use every opportunity to promote the Company's D&A Policy.
Encourage activities to compensate for the lack of social life/recreation and to reduce boredom and conditions potentially leading to D&A use.
Organize activities during the off-watch hours, encourage hobbies and educational activities, and ensure that provided recreation means are always available.
Make sure your crew knows you are always open to discuss any personal problems."
    },
    {
      "name": "Recommended drug panel cut-off",
      "content": "Below Table 1 lists the cut-off levels for a range of drugs and specimen types (urine, hair and oral fluid). Laboratories and contractors may test at levels lower than the cut-offs specified in Table 1; however, a lower cut-off than those specified is not required.
Table 2: Recommended cut-offs of drugs and specimen types"
    }
  ],
  "category": "DA",
  "normalized_topic": "Drug and Alcohol Control",
  "hierarchy": [
    "Chapter 7.7",
    "DRUG AND ALCOHOL (D&A) CONTROL"
  ],
  "references": {
    "forms": [
      "DA 003",
      "DA 001",
      "M 015",
      "M 000",
      "DA 002",
      "Q 006"
    ],
    "chapters": [
      "Chapter 9"
    ]
  }
}

sections.name: General Information
sections.content:
(*) USE only portable ladders marked with a unique ID number and suitability verified by the Safety Officer.

Safety Declaration prior to commencement of work: Following persons by signing below confirm the above circumstances and that it is considered safe to proceed with this work

Permit has a maximum validity of 8 hours. For operation in excess of 8 hours a new permit must be issued.

For working aloft, work permit is necessary at a height in excess of:

2 meters in accommodation areas, bridge, bosun store, paint locker, ECR and E/R workshop

1,5 meters on all decks (other than bosun store), in Cargo holds, and in machinery spaces such as E/R (other than ECR), Steering gear room, etc.

1 meter in all enclosed spaces (other than Cargo holds) and at monkey island.

gemini.title: DMLC Part II - Declaration of Maritime Labour Compliance – Part II

sections.name: 1. Minimum age (Regulation 1.1)
sections.content:
No person below the minimum age of 18 shall be employed or engaged or work on a ship.
Seafarer age verification is conducted prior to employment and onboard by the Master, to verify that no one under the age of 18 is employed.
The Manning Agent provides the Company with confirmation regarding the age of all seafarers.
Annual internal audits are conducted to verify conformance with these processes.
References:
MLC Compliance Booklet para 3.1
UMMS/Ch.6.1.3 Resources
Form C 001 Crew List
Form C 002a Seagoing Personnel Application
Form A 002 Company’s Internal Audit
Form A 003 Manning Agent Audit
Form A 004 Ship’s Internal Audit Checklist

sections.name: 2. Medical certification (Regulation 1.2)
sections.content:
Medical fitness of seafarers is ascertained by the use of the ILO/WHO Guidelines for Conducting Pre-sea and Periodic Medical Fitness Examinations for Seafarers and with Flag State requirements.
Every seafarer shall, prior to beginning work on a ship, hold a valid medical certificate issued by a duly qualified medical practitioner recognized by the competent authority, attesting that the seafarer is medically fit to perform the duties that he is to carry out at sea.
Upon arrival onboard, the Master or designated Officer checks the validity of the seafarers' medical certificates and, where relevant, colour blindness certificates.
The IMS establishes the criteria for checking the validity of medical certificates, and procedures with respect to certificates that may become out of date during the voyage.
Urgent cases of seafarers joining a vessel without a valid medical certificate are also addressed. A procedure is also available for seafarers that have been refused a certificate or have had a limitation imposed on their ability to work.
References:
MLC Compliance Booklet para 3.2
UMMS/Ch.6.1.2 Responsibilities
UMMS/Ch.6.1.7 Recruitment and Selection of Seafarers
UMMS/Ch.6.1.7.4 Medical Examinations
Form C 001 Crew List
Form C 002a Seagoing Personnel Application
Form A 002 Company’s Internal Audit
Form A 004 Ship’s Internal Audit Checklist

sections.name: 3. Qualifications of seafarers (Regulation 1.3)
sections.content:
As part of its IMS, the Company has procedures for checking the validity of appropriate certificates and/or dispensations as required by the STCW Convention, as well as the qualifications of seafarers providing medical care onboard and of ship's cooks or catering personnel.
The Crew Department ensures that all contracted seafarers have the appropriate qualifications and are holding valid and authentic certificates, in accordance with STCW and Company’s additional requirements.
The Master is also responsible for ensuring that records of all qualifications for personnel onboard are valid and available at all times.
In accordance with standing orders, personal safety familiarisation and ship specific familiarisation are given to each seafarer upon joining the ship and before commencing their duties.
References:
MLC Compliance Booklet para 3.3
UMMS/Ch.6.1.2 Responsibilities
UMMS/Ch.6.1.7 Recruitment and Selection of Seafarers
UMMS/Ch.6.1.8 Briefing and Pre-joining Familiarization
UMMS/Ch.6.1.10.1 Familiarization Procedures
UMMS/Ch.6.1.12 Training
UMMS/Ch.6.1 APPENDIX II Minimum Experience Requirements
UMMS/Ch.6.1 APPENDIX III Certificates and Other Documentation Requirements
UMMS/Ch.6.1 APPENDIX IV Senior Officers Familiarisation/Briefing Periods
Form C 001 Crew List
Form C 008a Deck Officers Familiarization Checklist
Form C 009a Engine Officers Familiarization Checklist
Form C 010 Ratings Familiarization
Form C 011a Master Familiarization
Form C 012a C/E Familiarization
Form C 004 Briefing of Masters and Senior Officers
Form C 014 Onboard Safety Training Program
Form A 002 Company’s Internal Audit
Form A 004 Ship’s Internal Audit Checklist

sections.name: 4. Seafarers’ employment agreements (Regulation 2.1)
sections.content:
Prior to joining the ship, the Company or its Manning Agencies issue each seafarer with a signed copy of the Seafarers' Employment Agreement (SEA), compliant with national regulations. A signed original is held by the Company and by the seafarer.
The SEA (in the English language) is also available onboard for seafarers to review their conditions of employment.
Each seafarer’s job description is defined. The job descriptions are available onboard the ship and are provided to the Manning Agency.
Some seafarers onboard the ship may be covered by Collective Bargaining Agreements (CBAs). A copy of the CBA is available onboard.
The Company has a procedure for ensuring that the provisions of any applicable CBA conform to the relevant SEA, details of which are kept with the IMS.
Sign-off arrangements and repatriation, at the end of a voyage or term of employment, are defined. Financial security to ensure that seafarers are duly repatriated (e.g. the P&I Certificate of Entry) is available onboard.
Annual leave calculations, health and security protection benefits, termination processes, conditions of employment, and repatriation are described in the agreements. Flag State regulations are regularly reviewed to verify that seafarer payments meet or exceed minimum wage requirements.
Each crew member has a record book to provide proof of employment onboard the ship.
The effectiveness of the SEA is assured in case of piracy and/or armed robbery against the ship.
References:
MLC Compliance Booklet para 3.4
UMMS/Ch.6.1.2 Responsibilities
UMMS/Ch.6.1.9 Travel Documents and Records
Form C 005 Policy Acceptance
Seafarer’s Employment Agreement
Form A 002 Company’s Internal Audit
Form A 004 Ship’s Internal Audit Checklist

sections.name: 5. Use of any licensed or certified or regulated private recruitment and placement service (Regulation 1.4)
sections.content:
Flag State regulations regarding recruitment are monitored. Flag State approved training is provided to the seafarers. Medically fit seafarers are employed irrespective of age, sex, religion, or race.
Manning Agencies used by the Company are licensed by the competent authority in the nations concerned. Where relevant, documentary evidence including evidence of inspections by the Flag State, RO or the Company to confirm that manning agencies in nations not party to the MLC or which have not been licensed by the competent authority are in compliance with the Convention, are kept with the onboard IMS documentation.
Personnel files are maintained for each seafarer. Seafarers’ rights to privacy are protected. Manning Agents provide documentation for each seafarer prior to joining.
Internal audits of the Company and Manning Agents are conducted to verify that requirements are being met.
Seafarers, prior to or in the process of engagement, are informed about their rights under the seafarers’ recruitment and placement services’ system of protection, to compensate seafarers for monetary loss that they may incur as a result of the failure of the recruitment and placement service or the relevant shipowner under the seafarers’ employment agreement to meet its obligations to them.
References:
MLC Compliance Booklet para 3.5
UMMS/Ch.6.1.7.2 Recruitment Through Company Approved Manning Agencies
Form A 003 Manning Agent Audit
Form C 005 Policy Acceptance
Form C 007 Instructions to Manning Agent
Form A 002 Company’s Internal Audit

sections.name: 6. Hours of work or rest (Regulation 2.3)
sections.content:
Working arrangements regarding hours of work and rest periods for all seafarers are defined.
The Company has elected to apply the minimum hours of rest which is in line with the STCW and MLC 2006 requirements.
The official schedule or table of work/rest hours at sea and in port is posted in accessible places.
Copies of individual seafarers' rest hour records are given to all seafarers onboard, and checked and signed by each seafarer at least once a month.
Any deviations related to the above requirements shall be reported as a non-conformity in order to be evaluated, assessed and take any corrective / preventive actions as necessary.
Flag State’s regulations regarding hours of work and rest are monitored by the DPA.
References:
MLC Compliance Booklet para 3.6
UMMS/Ch.7.11 Fatigue
Form SICD-101 Record of Hours of Rest
Form SICD-100 Table of Shipboard Working Arrangements
Form A 004 Ship’s Internal Audit Checklist

sections.name: 7. Manning levels for the ship (Regulation 2.7)
sections.content:
It is Company’s Policy for all fleet vessels to be manned with adequate number of seafarers in excess of those requested by the Safe Manning in order for a better performance of vessels’ operations to be achieved.
The Safe Manning Certificate approved by the Flag State is kept with the onboard IMS documentation.
Master and Senior Officers assess seafarers’ fatigue and provide feedback to the Company, so that appropriate corrective actions can be implemented.
References:
MLC Compliance Booklet para 3.7
UMMS/Ch.6.1 Resources and Personnel (Crew)
Form A 002 Company’s Internal Audit
Form A 004 Ship’s Internal Audit Checklist

sections.name: 8. Accommodation (Regulation 3.1)
sections.content:
Seafarer accommodation are designed and constructed in accordance with Flag State requirements for size of rooms (i.e., floor space, head room, number of berths, etc.), heating and ventilation, noise and vibration, sanitary facilities, lighting and hospital accommodations.
The hospital accommodation shall always be clean, locked and used only for medical purposes. The sanitary facilities provided for the hospital is used exclusively by the occupants of the hospital. When not in use, the hospital is inspected weekly and secured to ensure this.
High noise areas are distinctively marked and seafarers are made aware of these areas during the familiarisation process.
In case of high levels of noise and/or vibration in the accommodation, catering and recreational facilities, the ships management investigates the reason and initiates appropriate measures to reduce the noise / vibration levels.
The Company’s established procedures for planned, scheduled and internal audits and weekly Master’s inspections ensures that the accommodation, recreational and catering facilities meet the requirements of MLC on health and safety protection and accident prevention, with respect to preventing the risk of exposure to other ambient factors and chemicals onboard.
Ventilation, heating, and air conditioning systems are regularly maintained and cleaned in accordance with manufacturer’s instructions, so as to maintain the atmosphere within the accommodation at a satisfactory temperature compared to the outside temperatures likely to be experienced.
Where the ventilation system requires the windows, doors or port holes to be kept open, ships calling mosquito infested ports are provided with equipment and /or arrangements to minimize the exposure of crew to mosquitoes.
Lighting of the accommodation is also checked during the weekly inspections by the Master or the person designated by the Master, to ensure that it is safe, protected and sufficient in accordance with flag state standards.
Wash Basins are provided with hot and cold potable water, which is checked during weekly inspections.
Laundry facilities consisting of at least one washing machine for clean clothes, one for working clothes, with adequate drying facilities are provided on the ships and are regularly inspected and maintained in safe and hygienic condition.
Mess rooms are furnished taking into account the number of seafarers likely to use them, with due respect to their religious and social practices.
Separate sleeping room facilities for male and female seafarers are provided, if required.
In accordance with standing orders, the accommodation, mess rooms, sanitary facilities and hospital accommodation are weekly inspected by the Master or a designated Officer. The results of the inspections, and any deficiencies and corrective actions taken, are recorded in documents kept with the onboard IMS.
References:
MLC Compliance Booklet para 3.8
UMMS/Ch.2 APPENDIX IV Health & Hygiene Policy
UMMS/Ch.7.10.6 Health and hygiene procedures onboard
UMMS/Ch.7.10.6.4 Galley hygiene and housekeeping
UMMS/Ch. 15 New Acquisitions and Shipbuilding Projects
Form A 004 Ship’s Internal Audit Checklist
Form S 001 Health, Safety, and Hygiene Inspection Checklist
MoC for vessel acquisition

sections.name: 9. On-board recreational facilities (Regulation 3.1)
sections.content:
Appropriate seafarers’ recreational facilities, amenities and services, including social connectivity, as adapted to meet the special needs of seafarers who live and work on ships, are provided on board for the benefit of all seafarers. The Company ensures that recreational facilities are provided at no cost to the seafarers. Internet access and reasonable access to ship-to-shore telephone communications, where available, is provided to seafarers with charges, if any, being reasonable in amount.
Recreational facilities are located as far removed from excessive noise and vibration as is practicable. Weekly sanitary inspections of the accommodation also include recreational areas.
All ships are provided with a book-case and facilities for reading, writing and, where practicable, without cost to the seafarers, other recreational facilities, such as a smoking room, television, sports equipment, facilities for swimming, a library, facilities for recreational handicrafts and access to internet access and to ship-to-shore telephone communications, which charges, if any, being reasonable in amount.
The Chief Officer is responsible to monitor and report the condition of all recreations means on the vessel at least once a week.
References:
MLC Compliance Booklet para 3.9
UMMS/Ch.2 APPENDIX IV Health & Hygiene Policy
UMMS/Ch.6.1.22.1 Senior Officers' Spouse Visitation Policy
Form A 004 Ship’s Internal Audit Checklist
Form S 001 Health, Safety, and Hygiene Inspection Checklist

sections.name: 10. Food and catering (Regulation 3.2)
sections.content:
Seafarers on board during the period of their employment are provided with a sufficient supply of drinking water, and of food of suitably nutritive quality, balance and variety taking due regard of the number of seafarers on board, their religious requirements, custom and habit (cultural practices), which is properly and hygienically prepared, dispensed and served at no cost to the seafarers.
In accordance with standing orders, food preparation only takes place in the galley, which conforms to national regulations.
Ship's cooks and catering staff are qualified in accordance with national regulations.
Documentation concerning qualifications is kept with the onboard IMS.
The galley, food storage areas, quantity, nutritional value, quality and variety and supplies of food and water are inspected by the Master or a designated Officer at weekly intervals, with particular reference to hygiene. The results of the inspections, and any deficiencies and corrective actions taken, are recorded in documents kept with the on board IMS.
The Company has established that potable water tanks should be opened up, emptied, ventilated and inspected annually. Procedures on potable water are fully described on the MLC Compliance Booklet.
References:
MLC Compliance Booklet para 3.10
UMMS/Ch.2 APPENDIX I Safety policy
UMMS/Ch.2 APPENDIX II Quality Policy
UMMS/Ch.2 APPENDIX III Environmental Policy
UMMS/Ch.2 APPENDIX IV Health & Hygiene Policy
UMMS/Ch.3.3.2 Ships’ Functions/Job Descriptions
UMMS/Ch. 6.1 – Appendix III
UMMS/Ch.7.10.6.3 Catering Department
UMMS/Ch.7.10.6.4 Galley hygiene and housekeeping
UMMS/Ch.7.10.6.5 Fresh Water
Form A 004 Ship’s Internal Audit Checklist
Form S 001 Health, Safety, and Hygiene Inspection Checklist
Form C 010 Ratings Familiarization

sections.name: 11. Health and safety and accident prevention (Regulation 4.3)
sections.content:
Health and safety and accident prevention policies and programmes, including risk evaluation, are covered by the IMS. This is subject to internal and external audits and certification as required by the IMO ISM Code.
Occupational accidents are recorded within the IMS and the ship's official log, and reported to the DPA.
In accordance with the IMS, a Permit to Work system is in operation.
A structured training programme is implemented to train the crew in safe working practices and increase their awareness of hazards at the work place.
In accordance with standing orders and the IMS, all necessary, appropriately-sized Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) is always provided and must be worn by crew members when required.
A formal corrective/preventive action system is established to identify areas of nonconformity and for recommending changes to the management system affecting safety and environmental protection.
Procedures are established for a Safety Committee to be formed onboard that effectively addresses the health and safety matters. Minutes can be found with the onboard IMS documentation. Issues identified, including any issues that cannot be immediately resolved, are reported to the Master and the DPA.
Personnel records are maintained on each seafarer that includes training and medical history. These records are maintained in a confidential manner shore-side. Various publications and informational literature on health and safety are provided to the ships.
Internal audits are conducted to ensure conformance with requirements.
The Company has in place a ‘Harassment and Bullying’ policy, and implements onboard programmes for the elimination of harassment and bullying, taking into consideration the latest version of the “Guidance on eliminating shipboard harassment and bullying” (published by the International Chamber of Shipping and the International Transport Workers’ Federation). The Company promotes inspecting, reporting, investigating and correcting problems arising from harassment and bullying.
References:
MLC Compliance Booklet para 3.11
UMMS/Ch.2 APPENDIX I Safety Policy
UMMS/Ch.2 APPENDIX XII - Harassment & Bullying Policy
UMMS/Ch.3.3.2 Ships’ Functions/Job Descriptions
UMMS/Ch.3.4.3.1 Safety and Environmental Committee
UMMS/Ch.7.9 Procedures for Safe Work Performance
UMMS/Ch.7.9.3 Permit-to-work System
UMMS/Ch.7.9.4 Entry into Enclosed Spaces
UMMS/Ch.7.9.12 Working Overside or Aloft
UMMS/Ch.7.9.25 Personal Protective Clothing and Equipment
UMMS/Ch.8 Emergency Preparedness
UMMS/Ch.9 Reporting, Root Cause Analysis & Investigation of N/Cs, Incidents and Near Misses
UMMS/Ch.14 Risk Assessment (RA) and Risk Management (RM)

Form P 002 Hot Work Permit
Form P 003 Cold work entry permit
Form P 005 Electrical Work Permit

Form NCR 003 Incident Investigation Report

Form A 004 Ship’s Internal Audit Checklist
Form S 001 Health, Safety, and Hygiene Inspection Checklist

sections.name: 12. On-board medical care (Regulation 4.1)
sections.content:
The rights of seafarers to free medical care and health protection are set out in the SEA, copies of which are kept with the onboard IMS documentation.
Seafarers designated to provide medical care are qualified in accordance with STCW standards and undergo refresher training every five (5) years.
Hospital facilities are on each ship and outfitted in accordance with Flag State requirements regarding medicines and medical supplies. The vessel is provided with a certified Medical Chest in compliance with Flag requirements and inspected annually by a responsible persons designated by the competent authority for proper labelling, expiry dates and conditions of storage.
Records of Flag State inspections of the chest are kept with the onboard IMS documentation.
Medical evacuation and other emergency situations are included in emergency response plans onboard. Medical guide publications are provided to the ships accordingly.
The Medical Report Form, as required by the Flag State, shall be used to facilitate the exchange of medical and related information concerning individual seafarers between ship and shore in cases of illness or injury, with completed report forms being kept by the Master to ensure confidentiality.
The medical log is used for recording all medical treatment provided onboard and ashore.
Procedures are established for obtaining radio medical advice.
All relevant publications required to access contact details of coast stations through which radio medical advice can be obtained are provided onboard and regularly updated.
Medical Assistance onboard for Medical Emergencies
Country / Place
GREECE
RED CROSS CONTACT
GREEK RED CROSS
Telephone / fax / Numbers
Phone: +30-210-523-0880
Phone: +30-210-523-7515
Phone: +30-210-361-3848
ADDITIONAL SOURCES FOR MEDICAL ASSISTANCE CAN BE FOUND IN THE MEDICAL SECTION OF THE INTERNATIONAL CODE OF SIGNALS.
Where a seafarer has died during the ship’s voyage, the body or ashes of the seafarer are repatriated in accordance with the wishes of the seafarer or their next of kin, as appropriate, and as soon as practicable.
References:
MLC Compliance Booklet para 3.12
UMMS/Ch.7.10.16 Medical Attendance of Crewmembers
Form S 002 Medical Report & MLC
Form S 003 Medicine Log
Form Z 001 Safety & Environmental Committee Meeting
Form MI-105MR Injury and Illness Medical Record
Form MI-109-1 Report of personal injury or loss of life
Form MI-105G Ship Master’s Report Form

sections.name: 13. On-board complaint procedures (Regulation 5.1.5)
sections.content:
A formal complaint process is established onboard for fair and expeditious handling of the seafarer complaint alleging breaches of the requirements of MLC, including the seafarer’s right to be accompanied or represented during the complaint procedure, while ensuring that seafarers are not victimised for lodging complaints.
In accordance with standing orders, all seafarers are provided with a copy of the onboard complaint procedures in the working language of the ship.
The Contact details of Company’s representative and Flag Administration for registering a complaint are provided to each seafarer and posted onboard. Blank forms of the Complaint Report are available in special boxes onboard.
Target dates for resolution are established.
The Master has been given clear instructions and guidance to ensure seafarers are not victimised for reporting complaints.
References:
MLC Compliance Booklet para 3.13
Form MLC 001 Complaint Procedure and Contact Points (contact points will be plasticized and posted)
Form MLC 002 Onboard Complaint Report (blank forms will be available onboard)
Form MLC 003 Registry of Complaints and Follow Up

Recreational facilities are located as far removed from excessive noise and vibration as is practicable. Weekly sanitary inspections of the accommodation also include recreational areas.
All ships are provided with a book-case and facilities for reading, writing and, where practicable, without cost to the seafarers, other recreational facilities, such as a smoking room, television, sports equipment, facilities for swimming, a library, facilities for recreational handicrafts and access to internet access and to ship-to-shore telephone communications, which charges, if any, being reasonable in amount.
The Chief Officer is responsible to monitor and report the condition of all recreations means on the vessel at least once a week.
References:
MLC Compliance Booklet para 3.9
UMMS/Ch.2 APPENDIX IV Health & Hygiene Policy
UMMS/Ch.6.1.22.1 Senior Officers' Spouse Visitation Policy
Form A 004 Ship’s Internal Audit Checklist
Form S 001 Health, Safety, and Hygiene Inspection Checklist"
    },
    {
      "name": "10. Food and catering (Regulation 3.2)",
      "content": "Seafarers on board during the period of their employment are provided with a sufficient supply of drinking water, and of food of suitably nutritive quality, balance and variety taking due regard of the number of seafarers on board, their religious requirements, custom and habit (cultural practices), which is properly and hygienically prepared, dispensed and served at no cost to the seafarers.
In accordance with standing orders, food preparation only takes place in the galley, which conforms to national regulations.
Ship's cooks and catering staff are qualified in accordance with national regulations.
Documentation concerning qualifications is kept with the onboard IMS.
The galley, food storage areas, quantity, nutritional value, quality and variety and supplies of food and water are inspected by the Master or a designated Officer at weekly intervals, with particular reference to hygiene. The results of the inspections, and any deficiencies and corrective actions taken, are recorded in documents kept with the on board IMS.
The Company has established that potable water tanks should be opened up, emptied, ventilated and inspected annually. Procedures on potable water are fully described on the MLC Compliance Booklet.

Form C 010 Ratings Familiarization"

      "name": "11. Health and safety and accident prevention (Regulation 4.3)",
      "content": "Health and safety and accident prevention policies and programmes, including risk evaluation, are covered by the IMS. This is subject to internal and external audits and certification as required by the IMO ISM Code.
Occupational accidents are recorded within the IMS and the ship's official log, and reported to the DPA.
In accordance with the IMS, a Permit to Work system is in operation.
A structured training programme is implemented to train the crew in safe working practices and increase their awareness of hazards at the work place.
In accordance with standing orders and the IMS, all necessary, appropriately-sized Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) is always provided and must be worn by crew members when required.
A formal corrective/preventive action system is established to identify areas of nonconformity and for recommending changes to the management system affecting safety and environmental protection.
Procedures are established for a Safety Committee to be formed onboard that effectively addresses the health and safety matters. Minutes can be found with the onboard IMS documentation. Issues identified, including any issues that cannot be immediately resolved, are reported to the Master and the DPA.
Personnel records are maintained on each seafarer that includes training and medical history. These records are maintained in a confidential manner shore-side. Various publications and informational literature on health and safety are provided to the ships.
Internal audits are conducted to ensure conformance with requirements.
The Company has in place a ‘Harassment and Bullying’ policy, and implements onboard programmes for the elimination of harassment and bullying, taking into consideration the latest version of the “Guidance on eliminating shipboard harassment and bullying” (published by the International Chamber of Shipping and the International Transport Workers’ Federation). The Company promotes inspecting, reporting, investigating and correcting problems arising from harassment and bullying.

      "name": "12. On-board medical care (Regulation 4.1)",
      "content": "The rights of seafarers to free medical care and health protection are set out in the SEA, copies of which are kept with the onboard IMS documentation.
Seafarers designated to provide medical care are qualified in accordance with STCW standards and undergo refresher training every five (5) years.
Hospital facilities are on each ship and outfitted in accordance with Flag State requirements regarding medicines and medical supplies. The vessel is provided with a certified Medical Chest in compliance with Flag requirements and inspected annually by a responsible persons designated by the competent authority for proper labelling, expiry dates and conditions of storage.
Records of Flag State inspections of the chest are kept with the onboard IMS documentation.
Medical evacuation and other emergency situations are included in emergency response plans onboard. Medical guide publications are provided to the ships accordingly.
The Medical Report Form, as required by the Flag State, shall be used to facilitate the exchange of medical and related information concerning individual seafarers between ship and shore in cases of illness or injury, with completed report forms being kept by the Master to ensure confidentiality.
The medical log is used for recording all medical treatment provided onboard and ashore.
Procedures are established for obtaining radio medical advice.
All relevant publications required to access contact details of coast stations through which radio medical advice can be obtained are provided onboard and regularly updated.

In accordance with standing orders, all seafarers are provided with a copy of the onboard complaint procedures in the working language of the ship.
The Contact details of Company’s representative and Flag Administration for registering a complaint are provided to each seafarer and posted onboard. Blank forms of the Complaint Report are available in special boxes onboard.
Target dates for resolution are established.
The Master has been given clear instructions and guidance to ensure seafarers are not victimised for reporting complaints.
